Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts, timelines, diagrams) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: In “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt,” how do most of the headings connect to the paragraphs of the passage?

A.Choice: The headings give the topic for each section.

Key.Rationale: The headings do not provide topics.

B.Choice: The headings state questions, and the text answers them.

Key.Rationale: The headings do not state questions.

C.Choice: The headings state effects, and the text explains the causes.

Key.Rationale: The headings do not state effects.

D.Choice: The headings give the date and place for each section.

Key.Rationale: All but one of the headings provide a chronology of events in Teddy Roosevelt's diary.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which description states the overall structure of the events presented in “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt”?

A.Choice: a comparison of different places visited on a trip

Key.Rationale: Although Roosevelt does describe different places he visits, the overall text structure does not compare them.

B.Choice: a solution to a problem related to a place visited on a trip

Key.Rationale: Although Roosevelt does mention some problems on the trip, the text structure does not provide a solution to the problems.

C.Choice: a sequence of events experienced during a trip

Key.Rationale: The diary relates the sequence of events that Teddy Roosevelt experienced during a childhood trip to Europe.

D.Choice: a list of steps to increase enjoyment during a trip

Key.Rationale: Although Roosevelt does describe many activities he enjoyed on his trip, the overall text structure does not provide a list of steps to increase enjoyment on a trip.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to information in “Young Teddy Roosevelt,” why did Teddy enjoy the summers so much when his family went to the country?

A.Choice: He was able to ride a pony and play games.

Key.Rationale: The text states that “children looked forward to the summer, when they were free to ... ride their Shetland pony, Pony Grant ... and to play all sorts of make-believe games ...”

B.Choice: He was able to read books about birds.

Key.Rationale: The text mentions that Roosevelt enjoyed observing birds, not reading books about them.

C.Choice: He was able to visit museums and see historic sites.

Key.Rationale: The text states that Roosevelt enjoyed being in nature while in the country; this option refers to activities Roosevelt engaged in while in Europe.

D.Choice: He was able to see animals in a zoo.

Key.Rationale: The text states that Roosevelt enjoyed being in nature while in the country; this option refers to an activity Roosevelt engaged in while in Europe.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
In “Young Teddy Roosevelt,” which point does the author make about how Teddy felt while in Europe?

A.Choice: Teddy had fun with his brother and sisters.

Key.Rationale: The text states that although Roosevelt continually traveled throughout different countries, he also saw interesting sites and had fun with his siblings.

B.Choice: Teddy was surprised by how many places his family visited.

Key.Rationale: The text does not suggest that Roosevelt was surprised by how many places he visited.

C.Choice: Teddy enjoyed hearing different bird calls.

Key.Rationale: Hearing different bird calls was an activity that Roosevelt did at home in the country.

D.Choice: Teddy was nervous about leaving a pony at home.

Key.Rationale: The text does not suggest that Roosevelt was nervous about leaving his pony at home.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “... migrating swallows flew into the house ...”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the point that Roosevelt had fun with his siblings in Europe.

B.Choice: “... climbing on and off trains, steamers, carriages, stagecoaches, horses ...”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the point that Roosevelt had fun with his siblings in Europe.

C.Choice: “... jumping on hotel beds, having pillow fights, making war with towels ...”

Key.Rationale: This excerpt shows that Roosevelt had fun while in Europe.

D.Choice: “... throwing paper balls at them and chasing them ...”

Key.Rationale: This excerpt shows that Roosevelt had fun while in Europe.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from “Young Teddy Roosevelt.”
:box:“And Teddy saw sights that i͟m͟p͟r͟e͟s͟s͟e͟d him: some rare black Australian swans, the Prince of Wales, two boars and a wildcat in a zoo, and a tree that was over fourteen hundred years old.”
What is the meaning of the word i͟m͟p͟r͟e͟s͟s͟e͟d as used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: The word impress can mean to interest or to influence someone.
This choice does not share the same meaning as “impressed” and does not make sense in the given context.
This choice does not share the same meaning as “impressed” and does not make sense in the given context.
This choice does not share the same meaning as “impressed” and does not make sense in the given context.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account of the same event or topic; describe the differences in focus and the information provided.
Content: How are “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt” and “Young Teddy Roosevelt” similar in focus?

A.Choice: Both focus on the love that Roosevelt had for a pony.

Key.Rationale: Only “Young Teddy Roosevelt” suggests that Teddy loves his pony.

B.Choice: Both focus on the hobbies that Roosevelt enjoyed back home.

Key.Rationale: Only “Young Teddy Roosevelt” provides details of hobbies that Roosevelt enjoyed back in the United States.

C.Choice: Both describe the ship that Roosevelt took to Europe.

Key.Rationale: Only “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt” describes the ship Roosevelt took to Europe.

D.Choice: Both describe the experiences that Roosevelt had on a trip to Europe.

Key.Rationale: Both passages detail the experiences that young Teddy Roosevelt had while on a family trip to Europe.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information from two texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.
Content: Which statement from “Young Teddy Roosevelt” is best supported by the June entries in “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt”?

A.Choice: “One wonderful day in 1868, he didn't need to go to the woods.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not reference Teddy's visiting sites of historic importance.

B.Choice: “The arrival of a thrush in spring was news to be reported in a letter.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not reference Teddy's visiting sites of historic importance.

C.Choice: “They would spend a year there, traveling about, seeing historic sites, and visiting museums.”

Key.Rationale: This sentence is supported by the content of the June entries from “The Boyhood Diary of Theodore Roosevelt,” which detail Roosevelt's visits to different historical sites and museums.

D.Choice: “At the first glimpse of New York, he exploded with joy.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not reference Teddy's visiting sites of historic importance.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In the passage, a mother and daughter travel a long way to visit a market. Write an essay analyzing why the market is important to Elena and her family. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.
Read the sentence.
:box:The H͟o͟w͟a͟r͟d County l͟i͟b͟r͟a͟r͟y has a b͟o͟o͟k club on M͟o͟n͟d͟a͟y͟s.
Which underlined word has a mistake in capitalization?

Key.Rationale: “Howard” is part of the name of the library and should be capitalized.
The word “library” is part of the name of the library; because the name is a proper noun, the word “library” should be capitalized.
The word “book” is not a proper noun and should not be capitalized.
“Mondays” is considered a proper noun and should be capitalized.

SubTopics: Use commas and quotation marks to mark direct speech and quotations from a text.
Content: Choose the correct way to write the sentence.

A.Choice: The leader told the hikers, “When we reach the valley, we'll see a beautiful view.”

Key.Rationale: A comma is needed to introduce the dialogue and quotation marks are needed to mark the direct speech.

B.Choice: The leader told the hikers “When we reach the valley, we'll see a beautiful view.”

Key.Rationale: The comma and quotation marks are placed incorrectly within the sentence.

C.Choice: “The leader told the hikers,” when we reach the valley, we'll see a beautiful view.

Key.Rationale: The comma and quotation marks are placed incorrectly within the sentence.

D.Choice: The leader told the hikers, when we reach the valley, “We'll see a beautiful view.”

Key.Rationale: The comma and quotation marks are placed incorrectly within the sentence.

Content: Read the sentences.
:box:(1) Kate enjoys collecting shells when she is at the seashore. (2) She looks for shells __________.
Which phrase best completes sentence 2 by showing which shells Kate looks for?

Key.Rationale: This choice tells where the shells Kate looks for are located.
This choice tells when Kate looks for shells.

C.Choice: in the sand and shallow water

Key.Rationale: This choice tells where the shells Kate looks for are located.
Tthis prepositional phrase provides concise details about the shells that Kate looks for.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases for effect.
Content: Read the paragraph from a story.

:box:(1) Molly and her sister were washing the car as their dog, Max, watched. (2) Suddenly Max came up and made a big mess. (3) Molly and her sister had to wash the car all over again. (4) They had to give Max a bath too.
Which revision of sentence 2 best uses details to show what is happening?

A.Choice: Suddenly Max raced up, knocked over a bucket of water, and splashed in the mud.

Key.Rationale: The words “suddenly raced up,” “knocked over a bucket,” and “splashed in the mud” provide visual imagery that is very descriptive.

B.Choice: Max suddenly came over and got water and mud everywhere.

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not provide as much visual imagery.

C.Choice: Max suddenly arrived and made an awful mess with a bucket of water and mud.

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not provide as much visual imagery.

D.Choice: Suddenly Max showed up and made a huge mess of everything.

Key.Rationale: This choice is less descriptive than the best option and does not provide as much visual imagery.
